div.p: WHereas a Letter of John Perrots from Jamaica to Mary Booth, John Coopland, Margaret BradiÅ¿h and Francis Walker, bearing date the 12th. of the 4th. Moneth 1665. was produced by Robert Cobbet to Morgan Watkins in favour to John Perrot or intentionally for the clearing of the Å¿aid John from Å¿uch things as had been reported of him or charged againÅ¿t him to be inconÅ¿iÅ¿tant with Truth, and contrary to the leadings and teachings of the Principles and Å¿pirit of Truth, which we have received, and which he profeÅ¿Å¿ed though afterwards he apoÅ¿tatized or departed therefrom to hide himÅ¿elf under the Earth, or diÅ¿appear as in reÅ¿pect of the Lord and his Truth; Å¿o that the Å¿aid Letter by Robert Cobbet produced as aforeÅ¿aid doth not Å¿erve to the uÅ¿e, intent, and purpoÅ¿e for which it was produced, but rather to confirme and make good Å¿uch things as were reported of the Å¿aid John, or charged againÅ¿t him to be inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with Truth, and contrary to the dealings of God and the experiences of his Å¿ervants and meÅ¿Å¿engers whom he hath Å¿ent forth to declare and manifeÅ¿t truth unto many, who have in love received the Å¿ame, and do manifeÅ¿t their faithfulneÅ¿s unto God by continuing therein under the GoÅ¿pel DiÅ¿penÅ¿ation.

In all things approving themÅ¿elves as the MiniÅ¿ters of God, their Å¿ufficiency is of him; but they who Å¿peak of themÅ¿elves and act from their own wiÅ¿dom and reaÅ¿on, and the mans part only, and not from the Å¿pirit and power of God, are no more indeed then men of Infirmity as in reÅ¿pect of their MiniÅ¿tration; And if John was any thing more then a man of Infirmity, and if he was not unÅ¿ound and infirme upon the aforeÅ¿aid conÅ¿ideration, why Å¿hould he have made mention of it upon the account that he hath done, Å¿eeing he hath Å¿o much cryed down man, and would have man to be nothing, but the Lord to be all, who is not unÅ¿ound or infirme in any thing, if John was no more but a man of Infirmity then he Å¿poke of himÅ¿elf, and his Å¿peaking, Å¿tanding, and acting was of himÅ¿elf, and Å¿o his Natural parts and abilities were his Å¿ufficiency, therefore it was of Å¿elf and not of the Lord; and Å¿elf Å¿ufficiency we deny as inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with Truth, in reÅ¿pect of the MiniÅ¿try, and acknowledge to the Lord and his power to be our Å¿ufficiency, not that we are Å¿ufficient of our Å¿elves to think any thing as of our Å¿elves, but our Å¿ufficiency is of God, who alÅ¿o hath made us able MiniÅ¿ters of the New TeÅ¿tament.
